reviewText: *MINOR SPOILERS AHEAD!!!*Twisted is what I would say to describe "Perfect Stranger". From the beginning, there are little twists that only get deeper as you go along.It starts off with the lead character and decent (enough) actress, Halle Berry, who plays the part of a "reporter" if you will, Rowena Price. She is onto something juicy as she tries to blackmail the soon-to-be-senator, Some-random-guy-who's-mildly-attractive-but-pretty-unimportant-until-he-shows-up-as-Senator-way-at-the-end. He's gay, but not openly, and he is pretty outspoken about his thoughts about other gays not being deserving of rights. He tries to get his point across by speaking out against them as a "closeted straight", but Rowena has dirt on him; he has written numerous letters to a hot, red-headed gay male (as far as we know, anyway) and she plans to make sure this guy speaks out about the truth, squashing the hypocrite-soon-to-be-Senator's whole image.But the movie gets deeper and more intriguing once Miles, the strangely average but hunky Giovanni Ribisi starts to intrude on other people's emails and IOL convos. She starts going into chat rooms and meets trublu (who we later find out to be Miles himself - he's IN LOVE with Halle's character; even notes later on in the movie, "Why do strong women date weak men?" Or something along those lines) and ADEX, who is big shot company owner, Harrison Hill. He's almighty and powerful, but mainly due to his rich wife's upbringing, Mia Hill. She's a very pretty but very, VERY jealous and suspicious wife. She plays behind the scenes mostly, and contacts Harrison's right winged woman and lesbian, Josie.He and Rowena eventually get themselves into trouble when they bite off more they can chew. But before that, a couple of things occur in Rowena's life; she loses her "online virginity" by making a screen name, or having one made for her by Miles, and chatting with two men in particular; trublu (who we later find out is Miles all along) and ADEX, the guy she is trying to get dirt on).Anyway, back to the "bite off more than they can chew"; Miles brainstorms up a plan and thinks that it would be smart if Rowena, who now has a new job, working for someone who works for the current target, Harrison Hill, should install something into his PC to corrupt the data or something.I'm not gonna keep you here all day, but I wanted to hit on the major parts. Rowena ends up being someone you don't expect, as well as Miles himself. If anyone was "innocent" throughout this whole story, it was strangely Mr. Harrison Hill, who gets arrested in the end, nonetheless.These are my favorite lines from the movie, which occur at the end, and my new favorite quote!:It starts with a quiet hum, an empty screen inviting you, "Come inside," it says, "We're always open". It's a world where you think actions have no consequences. where guilt is cloaked by animinouty (sp?), where there are no fingerprints, an invisible universe, filled with strangers; inter-connected online and disconnected in life. It will steal your secrets, corrupt your dreams and co-opt your identity. Because in this world, where you can be anything you want; Anyone you want. You just might lose sight of who you are..."Everybody has secrets..."If it means anything, I watched this movie twice and it's the best movie I've seen in a long while. I totally disagree with the rating it has right now by a long shot, but what can you do?Almost a 4-star movie.
summary: A great movie by Hollywood's standards! 3.9 stars.

reviewText: This movie really has a lot going for it. Great actors, an interesting and unique premise, just the right amount of excitement, and a halfway decent twist at the end!"Perfect Strangers" takes audiences on a thrilling journey as one woman fights to uncover the truth behind the murder of a childhood friend. After evidence suggests Rowena's ex-friend, Grace, was murdered by a millionaire married man she had met on the internet, Rowena goes undercover at Harrison Hill's ad agency to try to gather enough evidence to put him away. With the help of her technologically savvy friend, Rowena begins an illicit online affair with the target of her investigation -- but as usual, things are not always what they seem...I really enjoyed this film. It held my attention, and kept me interested. A couple times I thought I had figured out the twist, but I was pleasantly surprised to discover I was wrong (don't worry, I won't give anything away!). Interestingly enough, they actually filmed 3 different endings -- each one with a different person as the killer. I'm satisfied with the ending they chose, but it would have been nice to see the other 2 alternate endings in the form of a special feature. Sadly, the only special features available on this disc are a "making of" featurette, and a couple trailers. I would have really liked to see more special features.As thrillers go, I think this is a solid film. Bruce Willis's character was a little stoic and one-dimensional, but in a quiet, creepy sort of way (which overall works to the benefit of the movie). Halle Berry is beautiful as ever, and even though I'm not sure the chemistry between Ms. Berry and Mr. Willis was exactly electric, I think they did what they could with the material, and played off each other fairly well.One of the things I liked most about this movie was that it was very adult. More and more often, studios are watering down the material to obtain a PG-13 rating in the hopes of appealing to a wider (i.e. old and young) audience. This movie is rated R, and it's not afraid to show it. There's sex, violence, and language -- but it also doesn't rely too heavily on disgusting gore to get it's point across (although, admittedly, there are a few disturbing images -- but again, it doesn't overdo it too much).Bottom line, don't miss out. I think you might be as pleasantly surprised as I was! 4 stars all the way.
summary: Meets All the Needs of a Good Thriller

reviewText: I was not interested in this movie... at all... after seeing countless reviews that panned the acting and the writing and the film. Too often these days, good movies are too few and far between. You can go to the video store and spend money out the wazzooo trying to find the good ones and usually end up being disappointed. So when a story she worked hard on is thrown away because it targeted a large contributor of her employer's and an old friend resurfaces with fresh dirt on a new subject, Rowena Price (Halle Berry) sinks herself into a new story.PERFECT STRANGER is one of those films that twists and turns and I appreciated the fact that it didn't insult our intelligence. It kept things in the realm of possibility and it was never dummied down. It was at times offensive and didn't hold back any punches. I also appreciated the fact that Bruce Willis, who played ad executive Harrison Hill, could have very well overpowered the film and its other actors, but he played his part wisely; low key at times, explosive at times, and always mysterious.PERFECT STRANGER was a complete surprise, that is if you listen to the critics. But it's a Pot Boiler of the first degree, worthy of a defiant dame like Joan Crawford ("Mildred Pierce," anyone?). Only here we have a cunning heroine who outs gay politicos who undermine gay rights (like Mike Rogers of blogactive.com), and takes down other powerful men who subvert public and personal justice in her job as an investigative newspaper reporter. This film is strange, but successfully explores the tension between personal and public justice. reviewText: PERFECT STRANGER is a fast-paced little crime mystery of a film that despite the innumerable sidebars of undeveloped information scattered throughout the script does manage to surprise the audience at the end.  The movie seems to be a vehicle for the beautiful Halle Berry to show off her skills and other assets: Bruce Willis is billed as a co-star but his role is minor and unexpectedly underplayed - a nice little tour de force for the king of action flicks.Berry plays a reporter with a man's nom de plume that allows her to uncover secrets of famous people for newsy stories.  Once fired from her job for uncovering the deeds of a Senator who is promoted by her newspaper, she teams her good buddy Giovanni Ribisi, a wizard of information about the media and internet spying, and the two go after a wealthy ad executive (Bruce Willis) when the murder of one of Berry's old girlfriends stirs both her wrath and her own secret demons.  The chase is on with Berry playing games of deceit backed by the skills of Ribisi. And just when the plot seems to have uncovered the murderer, then another line of story involving Ribisi and Berry explodes the audience's tracking of the crime with a rather good ending.Berry is fine in her role as is Ribisi with his: Willis is not on the screen long enough to form an opinion, a fact that is actually rather a refreshing twist!  The camera loves Berry in all her glamour and manages to turn sordid when the plot elements necessitate that.  It is  a fair evening's diversion and were it not for all the 'dropped ideas' that plead development, it would be a stronger thriller. Grady Harp, August 07

reviewText: I gave this movie a chance and it wasn't working for me. Of course we have Halle, who plays Rowena, a crusading reporter for a great metropolitan newspaper, who finds herself swept up in a bizarre chain of events when a friend of hers, Grace (Nicki Aycox) is killed under mysterious circumstances. Just before her death, Grace had given Rowena documentation linking her to a wealthy and powerful ad exec, Harrison Hill, played by Bruce Willis. Does Rowena share any of this information with the police? Of course not, because obstruction of justice is much more fun. Instead, she and her friend-Giovanni Ribisi constructs a plan on Hill.Early on in this movie, it feels as if a reel or two has gone missing, as characters amble in and out of the story with no apparent reason for being there or real connection to anything. If you've ever overheard two strangers having a lengthy and in-depth conversation about people you don't know, you'll know exactly how the first half of this movie feels. Character? Not really. These people are mere constructs, brought on stage for a bit of exposition every now and again when the director wants to sledgehammer a little more "plot" into this picture.The rest of the film proceeds along similar lines, with things happening because the writers and director say they should happens, rather than one event organically and logically growing from events that precede it. The so-called "evidence" that Rowena gathers against Hill wouldn't even win her a game of Clue, much less actually result in an arrest and a conviction. There's as much tension as you're likely to get in a 15 film, and the ending, while straining cinematic elastic, isn't totally far-fetched, and could even explain Berry's performance.Sadly, the performances in Perfect Stranger are no better than the script. Halle Berry is probably bringing her "A" game to this production. Unfortunately, that's the same "A" game she's brought to most of her pictures, including the regrettableCatwoman (Widescreen Edition). Bruce Willis, who was fabulous in the first fewDie Hard Collection (Die Hard / Die Hard 2 - Die Harder / Die Hard with a Vengeance / Live Free or Die Hard - Bonus Disc)movies along with a couple of drama hits, is obviously just doing this one for the paycheck, as he doesn't even try to hide the fact that he's phoning it in. His attempts to seduce Rowena are just cold and creepy, rather than sexy and charismatic, with none of the charm he's shown in past roles. Gionvanni Ribisi, wonderful as Dex inSky Captain and the World of Tomorrow (Widescreen Special Collector's Edition), seems almost embarrassed to be a part of this production, as he takes refuge in the drunken, alcoholic aspects of his character more and more as the movie progresses. Probably a wise choice. Out of all the actors I enjoy watching him the most. Another great reviewer by the name of Steven Hedge has put it well by saying that it has a TV-Movie Feel which was correctly so and should have been. Perfect Stranger could have been so much better or just left alone for that matter, indeed, a perfect miss.

reviewText: Every year you're pretty much guaranteed that Hollywood will release at least 1 or 2 movies that make you wonder, what were they thinking? Sometimes the film has a really good cast and no story, sometimes it's the other way around, and then there are those times when nothing in the movie works and it really makes one question the logic in releasing the movie. I for one hadn't seen a movie like that in a little while, that is, until I watched the Halle Berry and Bruce Willis thriller "Perfect Stranger"."Perfect Stranger" is essentially a story of deception and lies, and how nothing is ever what it seems. When a high-profile advertising executive (Bruce Willis) has an affair that appears to end in the woman's murder, her friend Rowena (Halle Berry), who just so happens to conveniently be an investigative reporter, begins looking into the murder. Rowena believes that the ad exec is the most probable perpetrator of the crime, but he keeps himself so well guarded that there's no easy way to get access to him. So, using her good looks, charm, and investigative skills, Rowena hatches a plan to get close to the exec by any means necessary to bring her friend's killer to justice."Perfect Stranger" is the kind of movie that seemed to hold a decent amount of promise, and I must admit that from the previews I thought that this would actually be a really solid thriller. But sometimes, much like the basic theme of the movie, appearances can be deceiving, because not only was this movie not all that thrilling, but the story was rather blah. It didn't seem to contain a whole lot of substance, sure there were numerous plot twists that were intended to keep the audience enthralled and guessing as to what would come next, but not much else was going on. As a result, the twists (which were the only parts of the story worth paying attention to) left audiences with a feeling that each one was either a convenient plot device to push things in the right direction, or in the case of the final twist in the movie near the end, just a cheap attempt at surprising the audience with the unexpected, regardless of the fact that it didn't really fit in with the rest of the movie.Though the movie's story was lacking in depth and plausibility, and heavy on coincidence (which isn't always detrimental to a film's success, but it was here), it did boast two very good actors with Bruce Willis ('Die Hard' series) and Halle Berry ('X-Men' trilogy) in the lead roles. Numerous times Bruce Willis has made some not so hot choices in terms of movie roles he's taken, ("The Fifth Element" is a good example), but he's been on a fairly decent streak lately with hits such as, "16 Blocks" and "Hostage", so I can cut him some slack. In the case of Halle Berry, she has also been on a decent hit streak of late with the 'X-Men' films and her turn as a Bond girl in "007: Die Another Day", but this Oscar winner is also the woman who made the stupid decision to star in the movie "Catwoman", so it's hard to say what she was thinking when she took this role. I would like to think that both of these two really solid actors were simply picking up a paycheck with this movie, basically wanting to fill some time in their schedule, and not really paying much attention to the story of the film. Because if these two actually thought that the story for "Perfect Stranger" was truly interesting after reading the script, I've really got to question their decision making capabilities, but like I said earlier I already do question Halle's just a little bit for making "Catwoman" (I know, I should let it go).What it all boils down to is that "Perfect Stranger", though it looked appealing from the trailers, was nothing more than an average movie (maybe a little below average). Featuring numerous convoluted plot twists that were way too convenient and flat-out annoying without adding any interest to the movie, and a rather boring story that failed to take off."Perfect Stranger" is rated R for violence, language, and nudity/sexuality.
summary: Do Yourself A Favor, Be A Stranger To This Movie...

reviewText: In the movie Perfect Stranger Halle Berry plays Rowena, a journalist dedicated to uncovering greed and corruption among people in positions of power (read: rich, white men) with the help of her tech-savvy partner in crime, Miles (Giovanni Ribisi). She writes under the name of David Shane, perhaps in an effort to give her stories more clout among those she seeks to bring to justice. Rowena is partying in a bar with Miles, celebrating the success of her latest story, a senator who has a penchant for sleeping with his male interns, when her boss comes in to tell her that the story is being shut down by the bigwigs at her paper. Rowena quits her job in a huff and runs out of the bar, only to be followed by a friend from her past, Grace.Grace seems to know all about Rowena's secret identity as David Shane, and hands Rowena a story that will help her rebuild her career and show the men at her paper that she really is a great journalist. Grace is involved with Harrison Hill (Bruce Willis), the owner of the largest advertising agency in New York, H2A. Grace met Hill in an Internet chat room and became sexually involved with him. Hill, a married man, breaks off their affair in due time, but Grace refuses to go away quietly. She wants Hill exposed as a cheater and a liar and she wants Rowena to do the exposing. Rowena takes Grace's evidence, but doesn't agree to do the story. When Grace turns up dead a week later, Rowena finally decides to investigate. She infiltrates H2A, with Miles's help, and poses as a temp to get closer to Hill. She wants to find out if he's the man behind Grace's death, but she doesn't suspect she might begin to fall for him in the interim...Coming from a person who likes bad movies and revels in the trash that Oscar winners go on to star in (eg, Catwoman, Aeon Flux), Perfect Stranger is virtually unwatchable. For starters, there's the director's penchant for extreme close-ups. And I mean extreme. At one point, I could see the inside of Bruce Willis's nostrils. Then, there's the newsboy cap that Halle Berry runs around in for most of the film, which I guess is meant to convince us that she's really a journalist. Also, we have Berry's gratuitous sex scenes with the hottie from CSI, which in no way add to the plot or continuity of the movie, but I guess if men don't get to hear Halle Berry talking dirty they won't feel they've gotten their money's worth. And let me not forget the fact that Halle Berry takes on a distinct lisp when she says the F-word (seriously, every single time it sounds like she might spit on someone), and she says it quite a few times over the course of the film. Finally, there was the end-of-the-movie voice-over wrap up, which I just cannot tolerate. You know what I mean (think Wild Things), when the movie's ending doesn't make any sense so instead a voice-over tells you all the clues you were supposed to have seen but didn't, so that the real story can be uncovered. It's a cop out and sloppy story-telling, and put the finishing touches on an already crappy film.There were 100 other things wrong with this movie that I might have been able to forgive if it had aired on Lifetime instead of in a movie theater. I laughed out loud more times than I can count, and this movie is billed as a "psychological thriller," not a comedy. Take my advice and rent Wild Things or Gothika or heck, even Glitter, and you'll be guaranteed to have a better time than wasting $8 to see this drivel.

reviewText: With star-wattage this high, you could reasonably have expected this movie to glow a lot brighter. And if you are expecting some frisson of sexual tension or action on screen, you are also likely to be hugely disappointed. That ending may be a supposed twist, but lacks the credibility to be satisfying, as the facts all jump out at the end like a cheap trick in a funhouse, rather than thought provoking moment that puts pieces together strewn through the movie, in the way a better scripted effort might have achieved.Disappointing, with suitably flimsy `making of..' as the sole extra. reviewText: At this point in her career, Halle Berry should probably give some serious consideration to firing her agent.  "Perfect Stranger" is just the latest in a long line of inferior films in which the actress has appeared since winning the Oscar a few years back for "Monster's Ball."Berry plays Rowena Price, an investigative reporter who goes undercover as a temp at an ad agency after a childhood friend of hers turns up dead in the Hudson River.  It appears that the friend had just broken up with the married CEO of the company (Bruce Willis) and was on the verge of exposing his wrongdoing to the public."Perfect Stranger" is an unimaginative, plodding thriller that believes it can redeem itself in its closing stages with one of those "surprise" - but actually utterly implausible - whipsaw endings that have become all the rage these days.  It doesn't work - and, in fact, all we feel is resentful, manhandled and cheated because we sense that the filmmakers have not been playing fair with us or abiding by the very same rules of logic that they themselves have laid down for us to follow.Berry may be one of the great beauties of modern cinema, but her acting, in this movie at least, leaves much to be desired.  Her shallow reactions and atonal reading of lines suggest that she needs to either hit some serious acting classes again or, at the very least, find roles that will challenge her to go beyond the surface in her performances.  Willis is his usual sturdy self, though the screenplay doesn't really give him all that much to do, while Giovanni Ribisi, as Rowena's fellow reporter, gets to perform most of the heavy lifting in the acting department."Perfect Stranger" is yet another disposable and instantly forgettable addition to the increasingly unimpressive oeuvre of Miss Halle Berry.

reviewText: Give this little thriller a chance.  It excels a bit more on the small screen than it did perhaps on the larger one because of its TV-Movie feel.Being a fan of both Berry and Willis must obviously color my perspective of the film, but I still think that it was well-acted, well-paced, and generally well-written although one can start to piece this mystery together before the end of the film (but not too much before the end).  This film has far too many twists and turns for me to adequately review it without giving away key elements in the story and other reviewers on here give away far too much without posting the appropriate "Spoiler Alert" at the top of their review.  Simply put, Berry is a journalist who consistently feels put down by controlling men in her life.  When her best friend is murdered, she sets out to work undercover for Bruce Willis who may or may not be the killer.  Giovanni Ribisi is her assistant who assists her with her tech problems, but he does so at a cost to Berry.  While fairly predicatable in multiple places, there are numerous unpredicatable moments with some clever twists to boot.For me, this was a well-crafted "little" thriller that admittedly has a TV-movie feel to it much like the old ABC Saturday Night Suspense Movie of the 1970's (where "Fantasy Island" got it's start).  Perhaps that is where most were unhappy with this flick in that it isn't that thrilling or graphic by any means.  It's a rather tame R rated film, but deserving of its R stamp nevertheless.  The story is familiar and has admittedly been done better in the past.  Willis has played this quiet but explosive underneath character before and Berry isn't doing any great acting stretch here either, so many may have dismissed this film a bit too off-handedly.  I can understand that, but the film is still enjoyable and the actors are definitely interesting and engaging.  Berry's sidekick, played by the ever watchable Ribisi [sp?], does steal the show a bit from the stars, but that's a positive aspect for the film, not a negative one.This film is definitely worth a renting, but being a Berry/Willis fan I'm off to purchase it.

reviewText: Astonishingly tense and wickedly complex, Perfect Stranger manages to put a new twist on the murder-mystery genre. If you are under the assumption that every whodunit scenario has already been realized, this film shines a new light on previously exploited suspect-to-murder combinations. Superbly acted and stylishly scripted, Perfect Stranger is an engaging thriller guaranteed to keep you guessing until its shocking conclusion.When a close friend of muckraking journalist Rowena Price (Halle Berry) turns up brutally murdered after giving her damaging information about the scandalous affairs of bigwig executive Harrison Hill (Bruce Willis), Price suspects him of the crime and begins a dangerous quest to uncover the truth. With the help of her friend Miles, (Giovanni Ribisi) the cunning reporter becomes a temp for Hill and quickly exposes a web of lies, deceit, and disloyalty that force her into a deadly game of cat-and-mouse that may find her the perfect stranger - and the next victim.In a world where every murder and subsequent mystery seems to have already been exploited, and every scenario already drowned in a sea of endless repetition, it's refreshing to see a film that realizes this and purposely tricks its audience into surmising the incorrect assumptions. Though the basic foundation may be recognizable, the methods for revealing it haven't been seen in quite some time. The recent trend in movies centering on a mystery or an overly complex storyline is to spoon-feed the audience at the end, and while Perfect Stranger is no exception, its use of unpredictable characters and plot twists provide an instance where you won't feel too insulted by the deliberate explanation. The clever script also craftily pulls you in the opposite direction of the truth, only letting you wander back on track for a moment before unveiling a revelation that reveals you couldn't have been further from it. The only real flaw to the presentation of its mystery is the use of several overly ambiguous flashbacks that hint at something diabolical, but never really shows you enough to figure out its intentions. Perhaps its mission is to provide more of a twistedly shocking climax, but leaving the audience in the dark for too long might blind them from the catharsis of the conclusion, and certainly robs them of the hope of deducing the mystery themselves.As most murder mysteries are, Perfect Stranger is a character driven story and this one boasts a talented cast with a unique turn for both leads. Halle Berry provides a compelling performance as the troubled heroine hell-bent on bringing down the man responsible for her friend's death, and reveals a slightly sinister edge to her character that places an interesting spin on how much the audience may be rooting for her success. Bruce Willis lends his charismatic presence as an adulterous advertising executive and gives a convincing performance that complements the mood of the picture; though it's a shame his devious aggression appears somewhat subdued. Giovanni Ribisi steals the show as a nerdish computer tech aiding in Rowena's pursuits who also reveals a darker and more calculating side than one would expect from character who is essentially a sidekick. He also provides the film's only real comedy relief, and a fantastic effort he gives, often causing hysterical laughter with his fiendish antics.Don't be deceived by the lackluster trailer - Perfect Stranger is a taut cat-and-mouse thriller with strong performances, deviously entertaining characters, and enough twists and turns to keep the predictability low and the suspense high. Though not graced with too hard an "R" rating, it does support a more chillingly serious tone with conflicted characters whose morals remain a shade darker, and while the outcome may not be overly original, the process in reaching it certainly is. Unless you still haven't forgiven Berry for Catwoman, this Stranger is one worth meeting.- Joel Massie

Rowena suspects a foul play behind the strange death of her old friend and starts her investigation on her own, using an alias. Her biggest problem is how to get an access to the "suspect"; our biggest problem while watching the film is that her logics are unconvincing in the first place, her methods impossible and results too good to be true. In this film not many characters are careful enough to hide important things in the right place or wise enough to distrust what is written and sent on the internet. By the time I saw the film's ending, I lost interest in what really happened.The biggest surprise for me during the long and twisted course of the story is the scene in which Bruce Willis' character literally hurls an employee across the room in his office in order to fire him.
